intro: Leandra erinacea var. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaf leandra, is a species of flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, wooded areas and has dark green, narrow leaves with a slightly hairy texture. Its botanical features include a woody stem, opposite leaf arrangement, and flowers that range in color from white to pink. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in partial shade.
